Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, watching my spouse stir their tea, the lines on their forehead deeper than usual. I knew something was wrong—they’d been quiet all evening. Remembering how important open communication is in our marriage, I reached out, gently asking if everything was okay. As they began to share their worries about work and some personal concerns, my phone buzzed. It was a message from my friend: “Rough day. Everything feels pointless. Can you talk?” I felt a pang of guilt. My friend always counted on me to listen, to be there when things got tough. But right now, my spouse needed me too, expecting my full attention and understanding. I glanced between my spouse’s anxious eyes and the glowing phone screen, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in. My heart raced as I tried to figure out how to be the partner my spouse needed and the friend my friend depended on, all at the same time.
